awd_titl_txt: Travel: NSF Student Travel for 2022 USENIX Conferences SOUPS 2022 and Security 2022
awd_abstract_narration:
The USENIX Security Conference is one of the most important research conferences for professionals to present cutting edge research of fundamental importance to advancing understanding of computer systems security.  Published research has specific application to security threats and vulnerabilities in computing systems; the design, implementation and implications of systems software; virtualization, system and network management and troubleshooting; cloud and edge computing; security, privacy, and trust; mobile and wireless systems; and more. This award provides funding for approximately 20 students to attend the 18th USENIX Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS ‘22), and 20 students to attend the 31st USENIX Security Symposium (Security ‘22).

USENIX conferences gather researchers from across the academic, government, and industry communities to foster cross-disciplinary approaches and to address shared research challenges. This cross-disciplinary emphasis makes them well-suited as a target for student
participation, and the important topics addressed in these conferences encourage student research and collaboration in critical areas of advanced computing. This award enables the participation of students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conferences. It also extends the impact of research presented to a broader audience inclusive of junior researchers from across the country.  For 2022, USENIX events are provided as hybrid events enabling both in-person and remote participation; this award supports students attending in person.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Outcomes Report, SOUPS/Security '22

This grant provided travel funding to assist US-based students to attend two USENIX events in 2022, specifically the 8th Symposium on Usable Privacy and Security (SOUPS '22) and the 31st USENIX Security Symposium (USENIX Security '22). 

SOUPS '22 took place August 7-9, 2022 in Boston, MA at the Boston Marriott Copley Place and focused on human-computer interaction, security, and privacy. USENIX Security '22, which was held August 10-12, 2022 in the same location, was a forum for latest advances in the security and privacy of computer systems and networks. Virtual participation options were also offered.

Participation in these and similar conferences is a valuable and important part of the graduate school experience. It provides students with the opportunity to interact with more senior researchers in the field, and exposes students to leading edge work in the field. This grant made possible the participation of graduate level students who would otherwise be unable to attend the conferences, and extends the impact of research presented to a broad audience of young researchers from across the country. Participating students at each event were offered activities to enhance their interactions with senior researchers and organizers, including speed mentoring events, a student meetup, poster sessions, and receptions. The NSF funding provided under this award allowed us to substantially increase the number of students we could support with grants for SOUPS '22 and USENIX Security '22. 

Any student enrolled full-time at an accredited US university or college was eligible to apply for a grant. Grants had two components: 1) registration costs and 2) expenses. For those students selected, USENIX covered registration costs by providing students with a registration code for full student registration. For the expense portion, USENIX provided a check to assist the student with costs related to airfare and lodging. Variations in the rates offered depend on how far a student needed to travel and the amount they requested (i.e., some students may stay with a friend in the town of the conference and therefore not have a hotel expense). We confirmed that the student recipients registered and attended the event. USENIX used other funds to support grants for virtual attendees.

The criteria we used in selecting grant recipients included:

  • Conference participation (e.g., presenting a poster)

  • Areas of study that significantly overlapped with the conference topics

  • Pertinence of supporting statement outlining the applicant's research

  • Application history, prioritizing first time applicants and those not receiving a grant in the previous twelve months

  • Students from institutions not traditionally represented at USENIX events

  • Students from historically underrepresented communities and minorities

  • Class level and financial need

  • In one case, since the events were co-located, USENIX made grant resources available for a single attendee to attend both events.

NSF funding supported a total of 48 grants for students to participate in the two events. 

  • For SOUPS '22, USENIX received 37 grant applications from students and awarded 24 grants. The NSF funds of $21,800 covered 20 of these grants, and all those awardees were enrolled at U.S. universities. There were 250 in-person attendees and 104 virtual attendees at SOUPS '22, which included 81 student attendees. 

  • For USENIX Security '22, USENIX received 188 grant applications from students and awarded 31 grants. The NSF funds of $28,200 covered 28 of these grants, and all those awardees were enrolled at U.S. universities. There were 836 in-person attendees and 205 virtual attendees at Security '22, which included 335 student attendees in total.
